trial_identification.studytitle: Individual factors associated with vaccine reactogenicity - a randomised controlled trial in young women aged 14 - 26
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Injection technique and individual characteristics associated with local reactogenicity to quadrivalent human papillomavirus vaccine in young women

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal development and function of the immune system

interventions.interventions: Participants will be randomised to receive one of the three injection techniques below: 1. Fast without aspiration Administration into the deltoid at 90 degrees. This involves a rapid plunge, no aspiration, & withdrawal of the needle following immunisation lasting less than 1 second. 2. Slow with aspiration Administration into the deltoid at 90 degrees. This involves a slow plunge, aspiration, & slow withdrawal of the needle following immunisation over a period lasting 5-10 seconds and 3. Slow without asperation - Administration into the deltoid at 90 degrees. This involves a slow plunge, no aspiration, & slow withdrawal of the needle following immunisation over a period lasting 5-10 seconds.
interventions.comparator: The 3 different injection techniques will be compared.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Local injection site reaction: Pain Assessed using participant held diary with pain scale 0 - 3 0= no pain 1= mild, still able to move arm normally 2=moderate, hurts to move arm normally or to touch 3=severe, unable to move arm
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Each day followng injection for 7 days.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Local injection site reaction: erythema Assessed using participant held diary measured in mm using a measuring tool provided (clear acetate with circles of increasing diameter).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Each day followng injection for 7 days.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Local injection site reaction: induration and swelling Assessed using participant held diary measured in mm using a measuring tool provided (clear acetate with circles of increasing diameter).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Each day followng injection for 7 days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived pain on injection as measured by visual analogue pain scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured immediatly following administration of vaccine.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy girls and women aged between 14 and 26 years of age.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Contraindication to receiving gardasil vaccine or unwell on the day of vaccination without a regualr telephone or who do not speak English

trial_design.concealment: Allocation to injection technique will be concealed at enrolment. There will be no attempt at conceament of the injection technique during the procedure. allocation will be in sealed opaque envelopes and revealed to the vaccinator at the time of vaccine administration.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: School of Population Health Tamaki Campus 261 Morrin rd Glen Innes Auckland 1072

fundingsource.fundingaddress: School of Population Health Tamaki Campus 261 Morrin rd Glen Innes Auckland 1072

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To determine characteristics of vaccination technique & individuals which are associated with severity of common adverse events following immunisation.
